Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Overcoming the Saturation Limit of High Intensity, Fully Coherent Raman Backscattering Laser

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The National Science Foundation uses the Early-concept Grants for Exploratory Research (EAGER) funding mechanism to support exploratory work in its early stages on untested, but potentially transformative, research ideas or approaches. This EAGER project was awarded as a result of the invitation in the Dear Colleague Letter NSF 16-080 to proposers from Historically Black Colleges and Universities to submit proposals that would strengthen research capacity of faculty at the institution. The project at Delaware State University aims to examine the feasibility of increasing the output energy in ultra-short laser pulses by over 100 times via the Stimulated Raman Backscattering (SRBS) technique. If this project succeeds, it could transform ultra-high intensity lasers, which in turn would have great technological and scientific impact. The project will strengthen research capacity and provide educational opportunities to students in the area of plasma physics. This project is funded by the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences.

An alternative to the present chirped pulse amplification for high power laser is the Stimulated Raman Backscattering (SRBS) scheme, where a resonant interaction in plasma coherently mediates energy transfer from the long pump into the much shorter seed. The backscattered short seed should undergo simultaneous amplification and compression, and since plasma is impervious to optical damage and has unique dispersion properties, its power can grow to extraordinary levels. Feasibility of SRBS lasers was demonstrated theoretically and experimentally. Still, despite some progress over the past decade, the maximum amplified pulse energy was limited to milli-joule levels due to early saturation. This project addresses obstacles in SRBS through an integrated theoretical, computational, and experimental approach, and aims to develop a solid theoretical understanding of the underlying mechanism for the early saturation, verified by simulation and confirmed with experiments; develop a scheme to overcome the saturation limit and prove that the saturation barrier can be resolved; and demonstrate how a coherent, single spiked, and single cycled petawatt laser pulse can be generated via a moving soliton cavity in a millimeter-long plasma.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Stimulated Raman Backscattering (SRBS) technique utilizes resonant interaction in plasma to coherently mediate energy transfer from a long pump into much shorter seed, providing simultaneous amplification and compression for the seed. Since plasma is impervious to optical damage and has unique dispersion properties, the amplified laser power can grow to extraordinary levels, making SRBS an attractive alternative to chirped pulse amplification (CPA) for achieving high laser powers and intensities. However, despite progresses over the past decade, the maximum amplified pulse energy was limited to milli-joule level due to early saturation. This project aims to address obstacles in SRBS to develop a solid understanding of the underlying mechanism for the early saturation, and to develop a scheme to overcome the saturation limit.

With support from this grant, we have successfully set up and run experimental campaigns of SRBS experiments at Jupiter Laser Facilities (JLF) of Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory. An ultrashort laser system funded by this grant was installed and synchronized at a precision of 0.5 picosecond with the lasers at JLF. Encouraging SRBS gains were observed in initial experiments and continue to be improved. The plasma channel formations were investigated under different ionization conditions and with an improved design of gas nozzle. Hydrodynamics modeling of the plasma formation processes were simulated to find the optimum ionization conditions and compared with experimental results, consistencies were found between simulation and experiments. These progresses help to gain deeper understanding and insights by running the SRBS processes with better controlled plasma conditions, which are needed to implement schemes to improve SRBS to be capable of tolerating more unstable plasma environment and better compete with other co-existing laser-plasma instabilities (LPI).

Eight Delaware State University (DSU) students were supported under this grant. Students involved in the project had access to state of art equipment and computation tools, and learned to tackle complicated laser-plasma physics problems with integrated experimental and theoretical approaches. Participating in experimental campaigns at LLNL during summer time provided students unique training experience with top-tier laser facilities in the nation and to work with many leading scientists in the field, as well as getting acquainted with their peers from other top schools. An ultrashort laser system is acquired and upgraded through this project, which is an important component of the essential facilities for developing a program on studying laser-plasma interaction. This program broadens and enhances the research spectrum of physics and engineering portfolios at DSU and will help to build the core infra-structure in research at the interface of ultrafast science and plasma physics.
